title: Read Classical Phrases with Case Particles
instruction: Translate these phrases from classical Buddhist texts. Focus on how case particles reveal the meaning.

questions.title: From the Refuge Formula
questions.transliteration: bdag gis dkon mchog gsum la skyabs su mchi
questions.correctAnswer: I take refuge in the Three Jewels.
questions.analysis: Three case particles work together: གིས (agentive — marks the subject), ལ (dative — 'to' the Three Jewels), སུ (terminative — 'as' refuge). Subject: བདག (I), Recipient: དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ (Three Jewels), Purpose: སྐྱབས (refuge).

questions.title: From the Four Immeasurables
questions.transliteration: sems can thams cad sdug bsngal dang sdug bsngal gyi rgyu dang bral bar gyur cig
questions.correctAnswer: May all sentient beings be free from suffering and the causes of suffering.
questions.analysis: Key particles: དང (associative — 'and' connecting suffering and its causes), གྱི (genitive — 'of' linking suffering to its causes). Subject: སེམས་ཅན་ཐམས་ཅད (all sentient beings), Object: སྡུག་བསྔལ་དང་སྡུག་བསྔལ་གྱི་རྒྱུ (suffering and causes of suffering).

correctFeedback: Excellent comprehension! You understand how case particles work together in classical Buddhist texts.
incorrectFeedback: Review the passage carefully. Identify each case particle and the relationship it creates between words.
